title: How Nissan leveraged its driver assist to cut traffic jams
content:
I recently learned of a rather interesting pilot study undertaken by Nissan together with the Contra Costa Transportation Authority and UC Berkeley that leverages the automaker's partially automated driving system, ProPilot Assist, to ease traffic congestion. The idea is called "Cooperative Congestion Management," which works by letting a car in traffic inform vehicles behind it.

Researchers from Nissan's advanced technology center in Silicon Valley have trialed CCM on I-680 in the Bay Area, logging about 600 miles. Starting with Nissan vehicles equipped with ProPilot Assist, which combines adaptive cruise control and lane keeping, they added the ability for those cars to communicate with each other, informing other cars about their speed and any hazards. On the road, they were able to show that the system reduced hard-braking events by 85 percent and cut time spent stationary in traffic by 70 percent.

But we're not talking about platooningâ€”the idea of having road trains of autonomously driven semitrucks networked together and driving in convoy was all the rage a decade ago, but mostly fell from favor once people realized the human truck drivers were needed for more than just the steering, accelerating, and braking bits of the job.

summary:
Key Takeaway:
Nissan's Cooperative Congestion Management (CCM) system, which uses its ProPilot Assist driver assistance technology, has been shown to reduce hard-braking events by 85% and cut time spent stationary in traffic by 70%.

Why it Matters:
The CCM system demonstrates how partially automated driving technologies can be leveraged to improve traffic flow and reduce congestion, potentially leading to more efficient and less stressful commutes.

Brief Context:
Nissan conducted a pilot study with the Contra Costa Transportation Authority and UC Berkeley, testing the CCM system on a stretch of highway in the San Francisco Bay Area. The system allows cars equipped with Nissan's ProPilot Assist to communicate with each other, sharing information about their speed and any hazards, which helps to smooth out traffic flow.

faq.question: How does Nissan's CCM system work?
faq.answer: nswer: The CCM system works by having Nissan vehicles equipped with ProPilot Assist communicate with each other on the road. The cars can share information about their speed and any hazards, allowing the vehicles behind to adjust their driving accordingly. This helps smooth out traffic flow and reduce the stop-and-go nature of congested driving.

faq.question: What are the benefits of Nissan's CCM system?
faq.answer: nswer: The main benefits of Nissan's CCM system are: - Reduced hard-braking events by 85% - Cut time spent stationary in traffic by 70% - Smoother traffic flow by allowing vehicles to communicate and adjust their driving - More efficient use of road capacity during congestion

faq.question: How is Nissan's CCM system different from platooning?
faq.answer: nswer: Nissan's CCM system is different from the concept of platooning, which was popular a decade ago. Platooning involves having autonomous semitrucks driving in a networked convoy, whereas CCM focuses on having regular passenger vehicles equipped with driver assist technology communicate with each other to ease congestion. CCM does not require full autonomy like platooning.

faq.answer: nswer: Nissan has trialed its CCM system on I-680 in the San Francisco Bay Area, logging about 600 miles of testing.
